title: Asia shares join global rebound
text:
Asian Stocks Join Global Rebound as Copper Rallies; Kiwi Jumps By Emma O'Brien 1 hour ago  Content preferences Done 
Asian stocks rose for the first time in six days, halting their longest selloff in almost two months after a bounce back in U.S. and European equities. Copper extended gains before an update on monetary policy from the Federal Reserve, while oil retreated and New Zealand’s dollar climbed. 
The MSCI Asia Pacific Index added 0.5 percent by 9:22 a.m. in Tokyo, following a five-day, 3.5 percent drop. Japan’s Topix index rose 0.4 percent and Australian stocks surged 0.9 percent. Standard & Poor’s 500 Index futures rose 0.1 percent after a 1.2 percent advance in the gauge. Copper continued its recovery from a six-year low, while Brent crude slid for a sixth day. The kiwi gained after New Zealand’s central bank chief said the current state of the economy doesn’t justify big interest-rate cuts. 
More from Bloomberg.com: DeMark Sees 14% China Drop as Stocks Mirror 1929 U.S. Crash 
Positive earnings from Pfizer Co. to Ford Motor Co., plus European deal activity fueled Tuesday’s equity rally, with global stocks snapping its five-day slump. Traders will be combing the Fed’s post-meeting statement Wednesday for signals rates may be raised in September, with odds of an increase then at 50 percent. A gauge of consumer sentiment in China is due as investors mull government intervention in the volatile market. 
“Often when a lot of stocks get washed out, we get a rebound,” Nader Naeimi, the Sydney-based head of dynamic asset allocation at AMP Capital Investors Ltd., which oversees A$160.5 billion ($117 billion), said by phone. “The Fed will be focused on global conditions. What’s happening globally can’t be totally ignored.” 
More from Bloomberg.com: China Stocks Sink Most Since 2007 as State-Induced Calm Shatters China Futures
Futures on the FTSE China A50 Index, a gauge tracking the country’s biggest mainland stocks, added 1.1 percent in recent trading, while contracts on the broader Shanghai Shenzhen CSI 300 Index were down 2 percent. The Shanghai Composite Index ended Tuesday down 1.7 percent, paring a slump of as much as 5.1 percent following Monday’s 8.5 percent tumble. 
Hang Seng China Enterprises Index futures rose 0.3 percent with contracts on the Hang Seng Index. The Enterprises gauge, which tracks mainland stocks listed in Hong Kong, fell 0.5 percent Tuesday. 
Baidu Inc., China’s largest Internet search engine operator, slid 15 percent in New York Tuesday after projecting weaker-than-expected sales amid the economic slowdown. Twitter Inc. reversed a gain of as much as 12 percent in extended U.S. trading, slipping 11 percent from its Tuesday closing level after executives struck a negative tone on the earnings call.
